column1: Between 15 September 2020 and 30 November 2020, will a country cease to formally recognize Taiwan?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']

Updating due to the timeframe and the fact that there seems to be little diplomatic movement, although China has increased its military activity vis-a-vis Tawain over the last two months. Other countries may wait to make any moves to see what the Biden administration will do on Taiwan.
Final update as question closes in two days. No change.
Fully decremented for time remaining. I will stand at 3%.
Sometimes it's useful to get in on a question toward the end when it's something you haven't researched before to get a feel for it.
i did not properly factor in time constraint (Nov 30) into my initial forecast
Time is up
No rumors of this being about to happen with 2 weeks left

There are 15 countries in the sample. The joint probability assuming 95% survival is around 45%. I adjust that slightly because I believe there is some path dependence. Overall, 40% Yes summarises well my conviction level.
update with two weeks left. The recent signing of the RECP is interesting, but not enough to turn another country around in a short amount of time.
I see no news to indicate that any such event is on the horizon.
There are currently no geopolitical events that would threaten Taiwan being recognized as a country. It's possible, but unlikely to happen within the next 2 weeks.
With the US blocking China, re: Sri Lanka, there might be a moment coming up real quick where China rights a big fat check to one of these remaining countries to goose the gander...
Based on my previous logic that there is a 8% chance that a country will leave in a given month, I'm updating the forecast to reflect the 20 days remaining: 0.08*2/3 = ~0.05
time update
Getting closer to the 30th
Decrementing 1% for passage of time. No developments that I've seen to make me think that anything has changed.

As certainty about who will be in charge in US may stay unclear for some time, bargaining with either Trump or Biden administrations will take longer than timeframe, so while it may happen, I think not until end of november.
Updating again given the deadline for recognition and no visible movement by the countries in question.
Initial thought, but still need to research the countries in question.
Dropping my forecast to 10% due to the passage of time with no new indicators of states considering severing diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
Reviewed the countries still in the game again. No new developments. Lowering percentage due to time left.

only 14 out of 193 United Nations member states: Belize, Eswatini, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, the Marshall Islands, Nauru, Nicaragua, Palau, Paraguay, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines and Tuvalu. The Holy See also recognizes Taiwan.

14 out of 193 United Nations member states: Belize, Eswatini, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, the Marshall Islands, Nauru, Nicaragua, Palau, Paraguay, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines and Tuvalu. The Holy See See no news but some of these countries need money and might do it for that. Time period short and US election looming so everyone probably waiting to see where the chips fall.
Lowering due to passage of time, yet amused after the Fidji incident.
The odds were low in the original forecast and 30 November is significantly closer.
(+1%) - China unable to control their staff apparently: https://edition.cnn.com/2020/10/19/asia/taiwan-china-diplomat-fiji-intl-hnk/index.html

Time is running short on this question. I am moving my forecast closer to 0%.

The most likely candidate in my estimation was the Vatican, however it appears the primary negotiated point in the Vatican-China agreement being renewed in Oct 2020 was an alignment of bishops and leadership making it less likely for the Vatican to have to move its embassy out of Taiwan to appease China.

Updating. I reviewed each of the 14 countries and the Holy See. Nothing in the news speculating a break in ties with six weeks left. The world tour by Taiwan's President last year seemed to shore up support from the remaining countries for time time being. There are no elections taking place before 30 November that could significantly impact this other than our own. @CatherineN - thanks for the update as well.
Reducing probability due to time remaining

“[América Crece] is an umbrella concept through which the U.S. has been trying to relaunch its attempts to promote private sector investment in critical sectors in Latin America, in energy and infrastructure, to counter Chinese investment in those sectors,” said Bruno Binette, an analyst with the Washington D.C. based think tank The Dialogue. [...] As part of the initiative, individual governments of Latin America sign Memorandums of Understanding (MOUs) with the DFC, laying out areas of focus for which types of projects will be included in the funding. The Governments of Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador have each signed on for $1 billion each in US government funding for infrastructure projects as part of América Crece. [...] Over thirty years after the end of the Cold War, the region once again finds itself in a macro-geopolitical conflict. Faced with increased investment by Chinese firms in the region, the Trump administration launched América Crece to advance the interests of US corporations.
Drastically culled after finally getting around to reviewing Lowy's "Pacific Aid Map" - https://pacificaidmap.lowyinstitute.org/

When I last considered this question, I was wondering (based on my base rate estimate that Taiwan seemed to shed nearly one diplomatic ally per year, on average) if a country had already ceased diplomatic recognition in 2020. Having tried to establish an outside view, I turned to a colleague who works in the international affairs community and who follows Asia, to find out more about that and get the Inside View. Here is what he said:
I affirm my forecast.
- As the deadline draws closer it is less likely a country will cease to recognize Taiwan.

Update - it seems like China is ramping up its anti-US/Taiwan rhetoric lately, perhaps because it sees that the U.S. is distracted with the election and POTUS' COVID diagnosis. China could use the upcoming 70th anniversary of the Korean War (or the "War to Resist U.S. Aggression and Aid Korea") to make another diplomatic and propaganda push.

Decreasing forecast by 2 pts due to the passage of time and the lack of publicly available indicators that any of the states that recognize Taiwan have plans to reverse course by 30 Nov. While the Vatican has made some overtures toward China, it has stated that the arrangement is religious, not diplomatic in nature (China has 12 million Catholics). The Vatican's stated intent is to maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan. https://nationalinterest.org/feature/can-united-states-and-vatican-help-taiwan-avoid-war-170031
At the latest U.N. General Assembly session at the end of September 2020, many of the countries who still recognize Taiwan spoke in support of the island nation's sovereignty.

Covid and US election result creating worldwide uncertainly therefore impacting decision making like this.

Updating my response after looking at Jtrusz's analysis. The four nations most likely to be swayed by increased PRC pressure are Taiwan's four remaining Pacific allies - the Marshall Islands, Palau, Nauru and Tuvalu. All currently seem resistant to changes in their diplomatic relations. Moreover, these nations looked to strike some form of formal alliance to unite against those nations that defected to the PRC in Oceana/Micronesia. Moreover, Taiwan has used the COVID-19 crisis as an opportunity to support those nations that formally recognize it.
Adjusting for passage of time. I don't know where the time goes, but it doesn't come here.

Lowering the percentage given the timeline. Additional information from research is provided. A total of seven countries broke diplomatic ties with Taiwan after President Tsai was elected in January 2016. Even though two countries severed ties last year, there has been no indication that any other countries are planning to sever ties with her re-election in January 2020. The Chinese do have "race to zero" campaign to sever all diplomatic ties with Taiwan so more countries will switch to the PRC over time as they apply additional pressure. Although the current 15 countries that have diplomatic ties with Taiwan provide trade, international support, and legitimacy benefits, countries like the US, UK, and Japan (informally aligned with Taiwan) provide greater benefit and voice to Taiwan than the other smaller 15 countries still in the fight. I am assuming that the countries still maintaining diplomatic ties with Taiwan are also smaller countries, that want to maintain a voice in the international community and this provides that avenue, and worth keeping. Worth keeping a closer eye on other countries in East Asia and the Pacifica and potential inducement measures going on there from China's "race to zero" to see if another country will fall in the next few months.
The clock ticks and I decrement the probability.

> In July, the Hong Kong newspaper South China Morning Post quoted a Vatican source saying that the Holy See could even move its embassy from Taiwan to the mainland. > “Taiwan should not be offended if the embassy in Taipei is moved back to its original address in Beijing,” the Vatican source reportedly said. > In July, Taiwan’s newly installed Archbishop Thomas An-Zu Chung said that such a move “could happen soon if the mainland Chinese government is more open-minded and receptive towards the Roman Catholic Church.” > The Vatican, and Pope Francis, have refrained from public comment on the continued abuses of Chinese Catholics by the government during the course of the two-year deal. The Holy See has also remained silent on the the detention of more than 1 million Uyghurs in a network of concentration camps in Xinjiang Province, which human rights groups have called a “genocide” and campaign of “ethnic cleansing.” https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/china-restates-one-china-policy-on-taiwan-in-question-on-vatican-talks-41951
Only 18 countries currently recognize ROC. There is very little evidence that they will change their stance in the next 90 days.
I see very little in headlines that would make any of the 18 countries that recognize Taiwan change an opinion during this timeframe.

I think the timeline is against me, yet I am raising as I understand Holy See (Vatican) is getting increased pressure in the last few weeks to diplomatically end recognition of Taiwan and move the embassy, this makes it more likely than I had previously, yet I am accounting mainly for time in my %.

After continued research, I have not found any additional evidence that a country that formally recognizes Taiwan will cease to do so in the near future. As a result, I am adjusting my probability down by one percent. I do not expect a country to make such a decision in the next few weeks, especially given the uncertainty around political and possible financial ramifications (impending elections in US and Taiwan) of that choice taken right now.

"[***]Taiwan[***] is not pursuing formal diplomatic ties with the United States for now, but there is "a lot" of room to further strengthen relations, Foreign Minister Joseph Wu said in an interview after unprecedented visits by two senior U.S. officials." https://www.npr.org/2020/09/22/915818283/formal-ties-with-u-s-not-for-now-says-taiwan-foreign-minister
Hattip @Jtrusz for an analysis that generates a probability that I can understand. The timeframe for this question is insanely short.

A good challenge. One that should make us examine our own worldviews before deciding. In the past, switches of allegiance to or from Taiwan have most often been decided by who pays the most in subsidies and/or fishing rights. For example, a low income nation hit by a severe hurricane or typhoon hitting would be vulnerable to financial largesse with strings attached. I make that twelve out of the fifteen exposed to this kind of pressure alone. And it is hurricane season, which makes this an interesting time of year.

My original forecast had the probability much higher (north of 60%). However, this was based on an internal view of the issue vice external - taking the frequency of times that a country actually changes its relationship with China - once every year or so. The span of time is very narrow, making the probability lower. Historically, notwithstanding the current Arab Israeli peace agreements (driven by delivering on an election promise) nations will wait out the US election to see who they will/will not have to deal with as a result of any major diplomatic change. International surveys reflect negatively on the US administration and this amplifies the "wait and see" phenomenon around US elections.
too risky with US presidential election in that time frame
List of countries that currently recognize does not suggest that one is likely to make a change in their position despite growing tensions.

I misunderstood this statement. It is not common for a country to change they way they recognize a nation. Without any major action, I don't believe it is likely that a new nation will cease to recognize ROC (Taiwan) in favor of PRC.
Its been a year since the last 2 countries and I cannot find any evidence of a new change now

Fifteen countries (including the Holy See) have formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China (ROC). Since 1999, thirteen countries ceased recognition of ROC in favor of establishing full relations with the People's Republic of China (PRC). Given the steady success of the PRC's inducements to drop recognition of the ROC, it is possible another country will do so before November 30, 2020. However, the Trump administration has stepped up public displays of support for the ROC with widely publicized cabinet and sub-cabinet level visits to Taiwan in summer 2020. HHS secretary Azar was the highest level official USG visitor to Taiwan since 1979. This very public support may reduce the chances of defection in the short-term. Likewise, the PRC's apparent suppression of reporting about COVID-19 in the early days of the pandemic may have reduced its appeal, but that is difficult to quantify. It seems possible but unlikely a country will stop recognizing the ROC before November 30, 2020.
Easy tool for China to use to counter US
- 1990 28 countries , 2019 15 countries (.43 a year) - 45 day period (.12) - .43 * .12 = 5%
The list is already pretty sparse and obscure, I'm not sure any listed are under pressure or stand to gain from dropping off any time soon.

Not very likely given that China is somewhat on its heals after mismanaging COVID and passing the National Security Law affecting Hong Kong. China has received a lot of bad publicity lately which impacts its sense of legitimacy as a world power. Therefore, China won't be aggressive in pushing further countries to dump Taiwan relations. In addition, the remaining 15 countries with diplomatic ties to Taiwan are small so not of significant concern to China; however, this also means that China could easily threaten or bribe (BRI) the small nations if the US or other world leaders don't offer support.
I do not see any catalyst for change
The PRC have flipped 1 or 2 countries a year since 2016 and there are similar nations among the 15 that recognize ROC.

While the chances may increase long-term, a shift is unlikely during the next 70 days. Currently only 15/193 (roughly 8%) UN-organized states recognize Taiwan as the ROC. It's been approximately one year since any state has swapped its allegiance to the PRC. While the U.S. has not changed its position, it has increased engagement with Taiwan, including the first cabinet-level visit since 1979. This may provide the smaller countries that currently recognize Taiwan with more cover to maintain their positions. Plus, UNGA is not in person this year, which would have been an opportune venue for the PRC to pressure states.

The chances grow more likely over the long-term as China continues to grow its power in the Region without being checked by the international community. I don't foresee another country making this decision until their is greater clarity in trade relations between the US/China, the US shift to the Pacific as a whole, impacts of COVID, and fallout from the Hong Kong NSL.

This just a starting hypothesis - will update once I do more research. Before conducting any research, I'll assign the same probability of breaking/not breaking diplomatic ties to each of the 15 countries that have diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

I think the a decision like this is probably not high on the list of issues that the remaining 15 countries (including the Vatican See) is planning on addressing given Covid. A deal like this probably involves some negotiation, more likely in face-to-face deals where China can seduce their counterparts with promises of largesse or lucrative trade and support deals.

With mismanagement of the initial phases of COVID-19, and increasing reporting of states taking a hard-line against the PRC, we should not anticipate any states that currently recognize Taiwan to walk that back.

The timeline is very short, but the pressure China is putting on many countries is also very high. With the vaccine question and the impact of Covid on many smaller economies, the environment could be ripe for change. Really unsure on this one. The outside view analyses I've been seeing on these comments has been persuasive.

Only 15 Countries currently recognize the ROC, Taiwan, as a country. I don't see any benefit for one of those countries to reverse their positions. The last two countries to stop recognizing Taiwan, Kiribati and Soloman, had economic pressures from China. With everything going on between China and Hong Kong, I don't see China making a power play against Taiwan.

China is becoming a pariah due to the coronavirus. Their economy is in trouble, and I recently watch a couple of Youtube videos which imply that China's economic problems could threaten the CCP. Saber rattling with Taiwan could distract the Chinese people from their problems so I give a 15% chance that China could strong-arm someone to renounce Taiwan.

Base rate is around 1/yr. However China is consistent and constant in suppressing political, legal, and commercial independence of Taiwan so it is likely China Foreign Affairs officials continuously work to have diplomatic relations of Taiwan dropped.
Taiwan is recognized by about 7% of the United Nations member states.

The US doesn't so maybe more countries will out of spite towards the US (Iran, Turkey, Russia, cuba). Or maybe Chinese regional hegemony will assert itself more forcefully. This is an interesting question and I'll be interested to continue following. 14 of 193 UN "Belize, Eswatini, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, the Marshall Islands, Nauru, Nicaragua, Palau, Paraguay, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines and Tuvalu. The Holy See also recognizes Taiwan"
Not likely before November.

With the world falling back into a more severe pandemic mode the likelihood that China will receive additional support from any other countries is limited, therefore support for Taiwan is not likely to fall at this time.
The PRC continues to expand influence, but most likely this will not result in further countries ceasing to recognize the RoC.

For a rough first stab at my forecast, I researched how many countries cut diplomatic recognition of Taiwan over a given time span in order to get a sense of the rate of Taiwan's loss of its allies. Between 2001 and 2020, 17 countries dropped diplomatic recognition, so that's 17 countries in 19 years, or rate of losing .89 ally countries per year - nearly one country per year. So if Taiwan is shedding allies at a rate of nearly one country per year, they are due to lose another friend in 2020 if they have not already done so. So next step would be to figure out whether Taiwan has already lost an ally in 2020. So far I have not found info indicating that a country renounced diplomatic ties in 2020, yet, so that would mean that Taiwan is due to lose another country this year. Therefore I think the probability is high; I'll say 90%. (If I uncover info that Taiwan lost a diplomatic ally already in 2020, I'll revise the probability closer to zero).

This is a broad question. I say China already fails to recognize Taiwan as its own country now. If the question were rewritten to include "...a country other than China..." then I would swing closer to the middle.
Using one of the several good forecasts on this thread to date to get an anchor of 17% (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1135422)

Very small timeframe. Despite the PRC's desperate vie for influence, I can't realistically see it happening within 45 days particularly before the US election. However, many pacific nations are in the tank because of the tourism decline, the alluring promise of a Chinese investment glut may entice them to switch allegiance. Will keep an eye on this.

combining baseline 17% https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1135422 and reducing by 3% because possibility of tactical waiting of countries on expected US foreign relations post election https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1134948
In the long run, China will minnow out most. Probably less likely in this 45 day period.

It looks like there are about 16 countries left that still have a diplomatic relationship with the ROC. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_diplomatic_relations_of_the_Republic_of_China In the last 5 years, there were 7 countries that ceased relationships with the ROC, pretty steadily 1-2 per year. That means on average, the chance of a country leaving in a given month was 7 / 5 / 12 = 0.12 = 12%. Given that there are now 7 fewer countries, its slightly less likely in a given month that we'll see a country leave per month (adjusted 0.12 to 0.08).
From 2015-2019, only in 2015 did no country cease recognizing Taiwan -> X = Likelihood of a country ceasing to recognize Taiwan in 2020 = 80% = 4/5
While possible, it seems unlikely at the moment where China is not exactly winning over hearts and minds.
Very few countries left and with the questions tight timeframe the probability is low.

Financial incentives appear to be a significant driver behind a country's choice to formally recognize Taiwan. Given the impending elections both in Taiwan and the US, it seems unlikely that a additional countries would cease to recognize Taiwan right now. Countries that formally recognize Taiwan may choose to wait for the election outcome and evaluate what it could mean for financial incentives, and thus continued recognition of Taiwan vs. China. If this question were longer-term, however, I think that more countries will respond to China's offers of money or other resources.

Increase probability since Paraguay has active discussion on this topic https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paraguay%E2%80%93Taiwan_relations#cite_note-19. US puts pressure on China by supplying weapons to Taiwan. China might make a move by pressuring other countries to cease to recognize Taiwan.

The research shows that of the 15 countries that still hold diplomatic relations with Taiwan, only the Holy See (Vatican) could or would not be coerced by the People’s Republic of China that is using its economic power to freeze Taiwan from the World Stage. The remaining 14 countries are either small, relatively poor or both and susceptible to the carrot and stick approach of hard and soft power that highly transactional. Also, the countries that are in the same geographic location have succumbed to the short-term economic benefits, plus the debt of an economic superpower. Therefore, any on country could be persuaded to alter its allegiance to Beijing, especially given the crisis created by Covid-19 and the potential financial and medical assistance that may be offered. The world is distracted by the US Elections, Covid-19, Brexit and China could use this period to gain extra leverage / advantage with the remaining countries that remain in diplomatic relations with Taiwan. China has an obsession with regaining what it sees as its rightful property of Taiwan and has a sole aim to take it over. This question is framed for an extremely tight time frame, so I suggest that no country will achieve a diplomatic change by then, but in the longer term, almost certainly.

I am giving a relatively high probability for this to happen: since we have had "Xi Jinping's thought for socialism with chinese characteristics for a new era" (I hope I did I not forget some part), the number of countries switching their recognition from the ROC to the PRC as the true and only China has increased. Simply take a look at wikipedia here:

There are only 15, so not likely that one will fall off in such a short time span. I actually googled all 15, and they each have either reiterated support for Taiwan in the past year, or Taiwan has taken special steps to ensure it continues. For example masks for Palau: https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3909369 Digital center in Tuvalu: https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3815366 ...et cetera.
It is not inconceivable that China will put pressure on a small debtor nation before the next UN General assembly.
Base rate since 2014 is 2% per year. Latest status of vatican - China relations is hacking done by Chinese government. More research of the other 15 countries is needed.

A two and a half month question, why? Hattip to @fisherdbus for doing the leg work and reporting on it in a generous way. Perhaps a country will accept an offer of covid immunization in return for recognition of the PRC. This would be a shrewd tradeoff for a national politician to engineer. Paraguay is wedged between two covid hot spots: Brazil and Argentina, it would appear that this would be a logical tradeoff to protect the population that may otherwise have a difficult time getting jabs. Given that the PRC has several vaccines both in trials and distribution this would seem to be a logical carrot and humane gesture.

It has happened before as two countries mentioned above dropped recognition in 2019. Paraguay is considering. https://www.americasquarterly.org/article/taiwans-last-stand-in-south-america/ Currently fifteen states recognise Taiwan as the ROC (and thus do not have official relations with Beijing): Belize, Guatemala, Haiti, Holy See, Honduras, Marshall Islands, Nauru, Nicaragua, Palau, Paraguay, St Lucia, St Kitts and Nevis, St Vincent and the Grenadines, Swaziland and Tuvalu. The Holy See is making a deal with China but its support of Taiwan will not be affected. China might try to buy off some others as covid has destroyed economies. Needs more research by checking country to country relationships.

Despite China's significant economic influence and military expansion, many countries are finding China's handling of COVID and coercive tactics with debt to struggling nations are increasingly unpalatable. Belize, Hondurus, Nauru and Taualu have all reaffirmed their relations with Taiwan recently and official visits to Taipei by the US and Czech Republic increase their international stature for support. If another country is to cease official recognition, it will likely be after November to assess the US stance towards Taiwan following the elections.
I can't find any indications that any countries are currently considering this. The time period is short so I'm putting a low likelihood.

Considerations: i) China has consistently been poaching allies from Taiwan since 2016 ii) On average it has been a few each year; assuming that rate continues there is a reasonable chance they will poach another one in the timeframe. However it is probably not greater than a 30-50% chance since the timeframe is very short. iii) US foreign policies in response may be discouraging Taiwan's allies from switching sides. For instance it's notable that after Pence cancelled a visit with the solomon islands when they recognised the PRC, the only nation to cease recognising Taiwan was Kiribati four days later (probably because it was already their plan). However it is unclear. The article below argues in some cases the policies may actually encourage nations ceasing recognition with Taiwan (though I'm not completely convinced). Nevertheless China probably will continue poaching most allies if they have enough determination given everyone's interests. iv) With all that said this research is very scant so it's possible I don't know what I'm talking about.
There's a fairly small number of nations that formal recognize Taiwan at the moment, and it's a fairly narrow time frame
Too early and way too complicated to predict.
On the face it seems to be an obvious "no" but ... need to research.

Low given timeframe. Winnie The Pooh has a lot on the go currently and standing in world not exactly in ascendant. Not a strong play for internal audience either. Best to bide time re Taiwan - potentially sowing discord or more amenable government from within.
"...will a country cease to recognize Taiwan?"
What an interesting narrow time frame... I have some research to do...

There are currently only 18 nations which recognize Taiwan independence from China. Most are small, relatively insignificant players in world affairs with significant internal issues and a sizeable population of poor. They appear particularly susceptible to Chinese inducements, much like two recent small Oceana states which dropped their recognition of Taiwan. Under an aggressive campaign to assert greater control over its perceived birth-right territories, Xi will likely take advantage of the environment within which impoverished nations can be persuaded to see things through the lens of Beijing. It does not help Taiwan that the US dropped its independent recognition of Taiwan in 1979.

Based on the small number of states that still officially recognize Taiwan (15 including the Vatican), it is unlikely that one of them would decide to cease recognition in this relatively short time period. Per wikipedia, an average of only 1 state per year has stopped recognizing Taiwan since 2012. A potential wildcard for this forecast would be direct diplomatic pressure by China against one of the four small island nations of Oceania that still recognize Taiwan.
